gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the school district, alleging that the school violated the First, Fourteenth, and Establishment Clauses of the First Amendments by restricting the Bible Club from distributing literature to fellow students during non-instructional time based upon the content of the literature.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the policy violated their rights to freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, equal protection, and free exercise of religion under the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, as well as the Equal Access Act and the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties settled the case for $28,500.00 in attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement agreement in which the plaintiffs agreed to change the message of the attachment to the candy cane so that it said "Happy Holidays from the Bible club."

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.

gold_sents: On May 14, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the Department of Education (ED) in the United States District Court in the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that regulations issued by ED "sharply limit educational institutions' obligations to respond to reports of sexual harassment and assault" and therefore contravened Title IX of the Education Amendmentsof 1972.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with responses to the complaint due on July 31, 2020.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex in educational institutions receiving federal funds.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2020, the U.S. Department of Education (ED) released a new rule, which excluded sexual harassment committed abroad from Title IX protections, requiring that it be perpetrated against a person in the United States.[SENTMARKER]The complaint was brought by COPAA, a Florida-based non-profit that operates out of Baltimore County, Maryland (within the Northern Division of the District of Maryland).[SENTMARKER]COPAA alleged that the new rule severely limits ED’s ability to respond to reports of sexual harassment and assault by sharply limiting its obligations to respond.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.

gold_sents: Financial advisors who sued their employer, Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., for race and gender discrimination in compensation did not state a plausible claim, so their complaint was dismissed pursuant to Title VII Section 703(h), which allows employers to compensate employees differently on the basis of seniority, merit, or quality or quantity of production.[SENTMARKER]The differences in compensation are only unlawful when they result from an intention to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: Title VII allows employers to apply different standards of compensation pursuant to a seniority, merit, or production-based system provided that the system was not adopted with a discriminatory purpose.[SENTMARKER]But the complaint did not adequately allege intentional discrimination in the No. 11-1957 first place.

gold_sents: In 2012, evangelical Christian business owners filed a RFRA challenge to rules adopted pursuant to the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, arguing that the rules infringed on their religious freedom by requiring them to provide coverage for emergency contraception through their group health insurance plan.[SENTMARKER]In November 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the contraception mandate did not substantially burden the plaintiffs' religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit granted expedited en banc review, and oral arguments occurred on May 23.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, 2013, the 10th Circuit reversed the District Court's injunction denial and sent the case back to the District Court, with instructions to consider two prongs of the injunction inquiry and to rule on the plaintiffs' injunction motion.[SENTMARKER]The next day, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' emergency motion for a temporary injunction pending the full injunction hearing.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted cert., and on June 30, 2014, affirmed the 10th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Court said other ways were open to the government to reach its asserted interest of ensuring the availability of contraception coverage.

gold_sents: These 2007 consolidated cases were brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona to challenge the "Legal Arizona Workers Act", which mandates investigation and prosecution of employers who knowingly or intentionally employ unauthorized aliens and requires the revocation of the licenses of employers found to have done so.[SENTMARKER]It also makes mandatory a previously voluntary verification process.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court affirmed the lower courts' rulings, holding that the Act fell within ICRA's savings clause and thus was not expressly preempted by federal law.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The plaintiffs challenged the Arizona Workers Act, A.R.S., which allows state courts to suspend or revoke business licenses of employers who knowingly or intentionally employ unauthorized aliens.[SENTMARKER]The District Court held that the Act is not preempted by IRCA because it is a licensing law within the meaning of the savings clause.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals affirmed the District Court's decision, holding that Arizona's law was a "licensing and similar law" falling within IRCA's savings clause and that none of the state law's challenged provisions was "expressly or impliedly preempted" by federal policy.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2010, the United States filed a complaint challenging the constitutionality of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2010, the district court granted a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of the law.[SENTMARKER]On December 12, 2011, the Ninth Circuit issued a writ of certiorari challenging the preemption of the Supremacy Clause.[SENTMARKER]The writ was granted in part and reversed in part.[SENTMARKER]The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth circuit was affirmed in part, and the parties agreed to dismiss the case.

United States, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down most of S.B.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction against the remaining provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 and while the parties were going through discovery disputes, the defendant filed a motion for summary judgment on March 17, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a response to the defendant's summary judgment and on September 4, 2015, the district court ruled in favor of the defendant with regard to plaintiff's claims under the Supremacy Clause, Equal Protection Clause, the Fourth Amendment, Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, the Due Process Clause, and 42 U.S.C. §1981.[SENTMARKER]Notably, the court also entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on count three claim which was appealed.[SENTMARKER]Finally, on September 15, 2016, both parties conferred and filed a joint case disposition in which the plaintiff settled for $1.4 million.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: 37 families detained at three ICE-managed family residential centers sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security alleging violations of their Fifth Amendment constitutional rights, violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, and violations of the Flores Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the congregate environment and unsanitary conditions of the detention centers make them a tinderbox for a COVID-19 outbreak.[SENTMARKER]They sought immediate release until proper protocols could be implemented.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order which was granted in part and denied in part on March 30.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered ICE to provide appropriate infection protocols for the adults (a similar order from another case, Flores, applies to the children), to comply with CDC guidelines for congregate institutions, and to file a report regarding FRC capacity, implementation of the CDC guidelines, the number of detainees released, and videotape of the living conditions at the FRCs.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and a motion in opposition to the temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the plaintiffs' later motion for a preliminary injunction demanding wholesale release of detainees on July 22.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, the court dismissed the claim under the APA and the writs of mandamus.[SENTMARKER]A hearing is scheduled for February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.

gold_sents: In March of 2002, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, acting pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq., commenced an investigation into the conditions of confinement at the Santa Fe County Adult Detention Center in Santa Fe, New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ concluded that the conditions and practices at the Detention Center violated the constitutional rights of convicted inmates and pre-trial detainees.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2004, the DOJ and Sante Fe County entered into a Memorandum of Agreement, which detailed the agreed reforms and set forth timetables for completion.[SENTMARKER]By its terms, the Agreement was to last for a period of three years, and remedy unconstitutional practices relating to: (1) medical and mental health care; .[SENTMARKER](2) suicide prevention; .[SENTMARKER](3) protection of inmates from harm; .[SENTMARKER](4) fire safety; .[SENTMARKER](5) sanitation; and (6) inmate grievance procedures (including court access).[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2009, after a two year extension to compel Santa Fe County to meet the benchmarks in the agreement, the DOJ allowed the terms of the agreement to expire.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ is no longer monitoring the county.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against Santa Fe County and its elected officials, employees, agents, and contractors responsible for the operation of the Santa Fe Adult Detention Center (SFCADC).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the SFCADC violated the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) by failing to provide adequate medical and mental health care, suicide prevention, protection of inmates from harm, fire safety, and sanitation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged violations of state and federal law and the constitutional rights of inmates.[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2004, the County entered into a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) with the DOJ to resolve the CRIPA investigation and ensure constitutional conditions of confinement at SFC ADC.[SENTMARKER]The County denied the allegations in the DOl's findings letter of March 6, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The County also denied that conditions at the Detention Center have violated state or federal law or inmates' constitutional rights.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.

gold_sents: The U.S. sued the State of Mississippi under the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. alleged that the State knowingly failed to provide adequate mental health programs for adults with mental illness and segregated adults with disabilities in their State-run hospitals.[SENTMARKER]After a four-week bench trial, the court found that the health system violated the ADA and required a special master to determine and oversee the remedial process.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On March 15, 1996, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, against the State of Tennessee, the Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation (DMH/MR) and the Memphis Mental Health Institute (MMHI), in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, Memphis Division.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 1996, the same day as the complaint was filed, the parties submitted a joint motion for entry of a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement the defendants agreed to implement all policies, systems, procedures and rules currently in place, to provide quarterly status reports, provide the government access to the facilities, records, patients, and employees of MMHI, and to confer in good faith on the provisions of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 1997, the Court entered judgment in accordance with the consent decree and terminated the case, retaining jurisdiction for necessary enforcement of the decree.[SENTMARKER]And, on September 18, 1998, the District Court (Judge Gibbons) granted the parties' joint motion for a stipulation and order, effectuating the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On June 21, 2005, the District Court (Judge Bernice B. Donald) granted the parties' joint motion for an order partially terminating the consent decree and approved the parties' stipulation for supplemental relief.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 15, 1996, the United States filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against the Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation and the Memphis Mental Health Institute.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) by failing to implement and maintain policies, systems, procedures, and rules.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a consent decree on September 18, 1998.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendants to implement, continue, implement, and/or maintain the implementation of all policies and procedures, as well as provide the plaintiffs with reasonable access to the facilities, records, patients, and employees of MMHI upon reasonable notice.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered on September 17, 1998.[SENTMARKER]Judge Gibbons no longer assigned to the case.

gold_sents: In 2007, the Disability Law Center filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the ADA, and the Rehabilitation Act against the Massachusetts Department of Correction.[SENTMARKER]The DLC claimed that the DOC failed to take into account mental illness when subjecting prisoners to long periods of disciplinary and other forms of isolation and segregation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in 2011, and the defendants agreed to make sure that mentally ill prisoners were not placed in isolation or segregation without a full evaluation and determination that such placement would not cause further injury; they also agreed to pay attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in 2015 as no one had requested to reopen the case since the settlement monitoring date ended.[SENTMARKER]In 2016 one of the prisoners tried to reopen the case since prison officials were violating the settlement agreement, but the judge refused to reopen the case.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 4, 2009, the Disability Law Center, Inc. (DLC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Massachusetts Department of Correction (DOC) on behalf of prisoners with mental illnesses.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DOC violated Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and the Americans with Disabilities Act by confining inmates with mental illness in segregation for prolonged periods of time.[SENTMARKER]In December 2011, the parties entered into a comprehensive settlement agreement (the "Agreement").[SENTMARKER]The Agreement required the plaintiffs to pay the expense of the monitoring required by the Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in 2015, and the plaintiffs filed a series of related motions in July 2016.

gold_sents: In November 2015, plaintiff inmates with hearing disabilities sued the Massachusetts Department of Correction and the Massachusetts Partnership for Correctional Healthcare under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and the Constitution of the United States.[SENTMARKER]After mediation, the parties settled in 2019.[SENTMARKER]Enforcement of the settlement remains in effect for a period of three years.

gold_sents: COVID-vulnerable inmates of the Maine Department of Corrections, seeking to represent a class of medically vulnerable and disabled inmates, brought this habeas action in an effort to force the Department to de-densify its prisons by releasing prisoners.[SENTMARKER]Filed May 15, 2020 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine, the complaint alleged that the Department had refused to grant medical furlough or home confinement to inmates; they alleged that this was in violation of the Eighth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The action was assigned to Judge John A. Woodcock, Jr.[SENTMARKER]Although the Department reported its first case of COVID in May 2020, the court dismissed the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunctive relief in June 2020.[SENTMARKER]Motions to dismiss the case and to convert the case to a different form of habeas were pending as of July 28, 2020.

On May 19, 2020, Petitioners informed the Court that the MDOC had reported the first case of COVID-19 of a person in Maine custody.[SENTMARKER]A judge should use his or her authority to grant such injunctive relief “sparingly.”[SENTMARKER]On June 25, 2020, the Court issued an interim order on discovery.[SENTMARKER]The Court declined to convert Petitioners’ petition B.[SENTMARKER]/s/ John A. Woodcock, Jr. into a class habeas petition.

gold_sents: On October 30, 2007, a state prison inmate filed a §1983 lawsuit against the Chief Medical Officer of the Michigan Department of Corrections' Bureau of Health Care Services and three unnamed individual members of the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, who originally filed pro se but was later represented by the University of Michigan Law School General Clinic, sought declarative, monetary, and injunctive relief, claiming that the defendants acted with deliberate indifference to the plaintiff's serious medical needs when they repeatedly denied his request for cataract surgery.[SENTMARKER]On May 30, 2012, following a reversal by the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals, the district court entered an order granting summary judgment in favor of one of the defendants based on qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]As of November 18, 2014, the case is ongoing against the remaining defendants.

gold_sents: In 2016, a transgender prisoner of the Missouri Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the “freeze-frame” policy of refraining from providing transgender prisoners necessary medical care for gender dysphoria unless they previously received such services violated the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, the court declared that the policy violated the Eighth Amendment’s Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause and issued a permanent injunction against the policy.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendants to provide the medical care necessary for the plaintiff’s gender dysphoria.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the court awarded the plaintiff attorney’s fees and costs.

gold_sents: This case is about the refusal of North Carolina's Department of Public Safety (DPS) to recognize Humanism as a faith group within the North Carolina state prison system.[SENTMARKER]On February 2, 2015, an inmate in a North Carolina prison and the American Humanist Association filed this lawsuit in the Eastern District of North Carolina against officers of the North Carolina Department of Public Safety that are involved in policy decisions related to recognition of faith groups in state prison under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]They alleged violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, and on March 29, 2018, Judge Terrence W. Boyle granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]He entered a permanent injunction ordering DPS to recognize Humanism as a faith group and to permit a Humanist study group to meet within North Carolina state prisons on the same terms as other faiths are allowed and entered declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]The court also awarded nominal damages and attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]Since the entering of the permanent injunction, there has been no activity in this case.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction remains in effect.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 28, 2017, the American Humanist Association (AHA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Public Safety (DPS) on behalf of inmates seeking to form a Humanist study group in the state's prisons.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory judgment, permanent injunctive relief, nominal damages, and attorney's fees Compl.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment on July 28, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On March 4, 2018, the parties filed a motion to dismiss, and the court granted the motion on March 5, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion for a permanent injunction on July 28.[SENTMARKER]On July 29, 2018, the court denied the motion.

gold_sents: This was a prison medical care case filed in 2002 in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey, seeking damages and an injunction against contract medical care providers and New Jersey corrections officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs that the New Jersey prison system was failing to treat them for Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]By the time the court adjudicated the class action issue, in May 2008, the New Jersey Department of Corrections had adopted major changes in how prisoners with HCV were treated; it updated its procedures to match those of the federal Bureau of Prisons, and "backscreened" all the prisoners willing to be screened for the virus.[SENTMARKER]Given that the injunctive relief requested by the plaintiffs was this same set of reforms, Judge Hillman denied the request for injunctive relief as moot.[SENTMARKER]As to two individual class members who had HCV, the court held there was sufficient evidence in the record to go to trial on their constitutional claims (though not on their Americans with Disabilities Act claims), and denied the state's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2009, the case settled for money damages.[SENTMARKER](However, it seems from some papers filed by one of the plaintiffs that he may never actually have received  his money.[SENTMARKER]But when he sought the assistance of the court in enforcing the settlement against his lawyer, Judge Hillman ruled that the court lacked jurisdiction, and directed him to file a collection action in state court.  )

gold_sents: On January 21, 2003, an Oklahoma Department of Corrections prisoner filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that his Constitutional rights under the Free Exercise Clause were being violated by the Oklahoma Department of Corrections' refusal to provide him with a Kosher diet.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated to include the complaints of two other prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The prisoners won both preliminary and permanent injunctive relief requiring the Oklahoma Department of Corrections to provide them a Kosher diet at no personal cost.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction, issued February 8, 2006, ordered the Director of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections 'to immediately provide to the plaintiffs Kosher diets at no cost, [while complying with nutritional requirements currently applicable to all other ODOC prisoners].'[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2012 the Court found that the judgment entered in this case only applies to the claims pursued by the three named plaintiffs, and the permanent injunction relief does not apply to all Oklahoma Department of Corrections inmates.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 26, 2006, a group of inmates in the Oklahoma Department of Corrections ("DOC") filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were violating their constitutional rights by failing to provide them with Kosher diets that complied with all nutritional requirements and standards currently applicable to the diets served to all other inmates in DOC custody.[SENTMARKER]On February 8, 2006, Judge West issued a perment injunction ordering Defendant Jones, in his official capacity as the ODOC Director, to "imly provide to the plaintiffs Kosher diets at no cost"

gold_sents: On November 7, 2013, a trans woman housed in a mens prison in Oklahoma filed a pro se case against prison staff and administration in the District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]She claims that she has been denied appropriate transition related care and accommodations, amounting to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]Her request for a TRO and preliminary injunction were denied at the district court level, and the circuit court affirmed the denial of the preliminary injunction without comment on the TRO for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2015, the district court granted defendants' motion to dismiss, dismissing the claims against all defendants in their individual capacities without prejudice, and all the claims against them in their official capacity with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]Though the plaintiff objected to the dismissal, the Court denied her motion and affirmed the dismissal.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 7, 2011, a transgender woman filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma against the Oklahoma City Health Care System (JHCC) and several of its employees.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated her Eighth Amendment rights by failing to provide her with a bra, housing her in the 'A.C.'[SENTMARKER]and failing to comply with the protocol she believes appropriate for the treatment of her gender identity disorder (GID) by not re-starting her hormone treatment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for IFP on January 21, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The complaint was dismissed on May 15, 2013 and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 27, 2012, plaintiff, a male prisoner, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Middle District of Pennsylvania under Bivens against the Federal Bureau of Prisons.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff claimed that the defendants violated plaintiff's right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution by forcing him to share a cell with a hostile prisoner, which caused a threat of violence, and by placing him in painful restraints that caused injury for prolonged periods on multiple occasions for refusing dangerous cell assignments with hostile prisoners; and that defendants violated his right to due process under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution by depriving him of any meaningful process prior to and during their use of punitive measures against him.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2013, the U.S. District Court (Judge William B. Nealon) granted in part and denied in part defendant's motion to dismiss, declining to certify the class.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit reversed and remanded the district court's denial of class action certification on June 15, 2016, but the district court again denied certification.[SENTMARKER]Litigation is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2011, a federal inmate filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Federal Bureau of Narcotics.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that he was forced to share a cell with a known hostile inmate, facing the threat of violence from that cell pairing, and that he had been placed in restraints on multiple occasions for refusing dangerous cell assignments with hostile inmates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated his Fifth Amendment rights by depriving him of any meaningful process prior to and during their use of punitive measures against him, including but not limited to, subjecting him to hard "ambulatory" restraints and four-point restraints, and by taking those punitive measures in an arbitrary manner without any legitimate penological purpose.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied class certification for lack of commonality and typicality, finding that the plaintiff alleged a common threat of injury to the inmate population as a whole.

gold_sents: In 2015, a prisoner at the Mahanoy State Correctional Institute filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants denied him necessary medical treatment, in violation of his Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]In May 2018, the district judge denied the defendants' motions to dismiss, which the defendants appealed to the Third Circuit.[SENTMARKER]As of March 23, 2020, the case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: 47 inmates at the Beaumont Federal Correctional Institution in Midland, Texas filed a complaint against the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act. gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. Davis (2:14-cv-13) and Cobb v. Morris (2:14-cv-22) with this case, as the two cases also were brought by Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit and involved RLUIPA grooming policy claims moving towards trial.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, Judge Ramos granted plaintiffs’ request for injunctive relief permitting them to grow their hair long, consistent with their Native American religious beliefs and entered a final judgment on February 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed, but moved to dismiss the appeal shortly after.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit granted the motion to dismiss the appeal on July 9, 2019.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 21, 2012, inmates at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (D.C.J.)[SENTMARKER]filed a lawsuit under RLUIPA against the TDCJ in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that TDCJ policies burdened the exercise of their religious beliefs by preventing them from smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, wearing a religiously significant "medicine bag" other than within their cell, and growing long hair or alternatively, a kouplock, which is "a one inch square section of hair at the base of the skull"<n>The district court dismissed the case as frivolous, but the plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on February 27, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 26, 2003, two separate suits were filed against the City of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department (OPD), and related defendants, in federal court.[SENTMARKER]The suits were filed in response to the OPD's actions on April 7 at a peaceful antiwar demonstration at the Port of Oakland.[SENTMARKER]The Police, without giving sufficient notice to disperse and without provocation, barraged demonstrators with a variety of "less-lethal" munitions, while blocking the main exit routes.[SENTMARKER]Police pursued demonstrators and others present when they attempted to disperse, while continuing to fire at them and intentionally strike them with motorcycles.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2003, the Court ordered that the cases be officially related and heard before the same judge.[SENTMARKER]One of the two cases, Local 10 ILWU v. City of Oakland, was filed as a class-action on behalf of all persons who attended the April 7 demonstration.[SENTMARKER]City of Oakland, was filed as a class-action on behalf of all persons who attended the April 7 demonstration.[SENTMARKER]The suit also named as plaintiffs Local 10 of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, plus nine of its members who were "standing by" in the vicinity of the demonstration but not active participants in it.[SENTMARKER]The other suit, Coles v. City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD.[SENTMARKER]City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD.[SENTMARKER]In both cases, Plaintiffs sought compensatory, exemplary, and punitive damages, as well as to recover legal costs.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declaratory judgments holding the Defendants' actions to be unlawful violations of the Plaintiffs' rights under the Constitutions of the U.S. and of California and of statutory law.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctions that among other things would prohibit the Defendants from unlawfully interference with the constitutional and statutory rights of participants in public demonstrations and protests.[SENTMARKER]On December 24, 2004, the parties entered a court-approved partial settlement addressing the Plaintiffs' claims for injunctive relief to the extent that those claims related to the Defendants' crowd control policies.[SENTMARKER]Oakland adopted a new official Crowd Control Policy that forbade the police from dispersing crowds that had not behaved illegally or that did not pose a clear and present danger of imminent violence.[SENTMARKER]It also forbade the indiscriminate use of less-lethal weapons directly against crowds, even when specific individuals in the group were violent.[SENTMARKER]The remaining issues eventually settled, with awards of damages and attorneys' fees well in excess of $1,000,000.

gold_sents: The plaintiff filed the lawsuit on November 29, 2012 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, a demonstrator involved in the Occupy Oakland protest movement, alleged that when he was returning home from a protest, two Oakland police officers brutally beat him with clubs, sprayed painful chemicals in his face, and arrested him.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and alleged that the polices' actions violated his First Amendment right to free speech, his Fourteenth Amendment rights to equal protection and due process, and the Fourth Amendment ban on unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]After two settlement conferences, the parties reached a settlement agreement which was ordered by the court on January 30, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The Defendants paid $645,000 to the plaintiff to compensate his claims including attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.

gold_sents: On Dec.[SENTMARKER]3, 1997, Barbara Grutter brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the University of Michigan Law School.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that, in denying her admission, the school discriminated against her on the basis of her race, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which held that the law school's desire to obtain a "critical mass" of underrepresented minority students counted as a narrowly tailored use of race in its admissions process and was not unconstitutional.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a group of Georgia residents filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the Georgia Secretary of State, alleging that Georgia's ballot access restrictions unconstitutionally burden their rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs pointed to the public health risks associated with conducting a signature-gathering campaign as the source of their increased burden.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the Secretary to reduce the relevant signature requirements by 30% for the 2020 general election.

gold_sents: On April 22, four individuals facing a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19 and the Family Unit, a non-profit organization, filed an action against the enforcement of South Carolina’s witness requirement applied to absentee voters, and the excuse requirement applied in order to vote by an absentee ballot.[SENTMARKER]On May 12, the South Carolina General Assembly passed legislation allowing all qualified South Carolina voters to vote by absentee ballot for the June primaries.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, the court granted the plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions in part, pertaining to the witness requirement.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the Witness Requirement was enjoined for the November 2020 General Election in a separate case, and the district court stayed the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2011 voters in Wisconsin filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their fundamental right to vote had been violated by Act 23, Wisconsin's law implementing a voter ID requirement.[SENTMARKER]After much litigation, in 2016 a judge granted a preliminary injunction allowing voters without IDs to sign an affidavit in place of the ID requirement for the 2016 presidential election.[SENTMARKER]The state appealed the injunction to the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit stayed the injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]As of December 2019, the appeal remained pending in the Seventh Circuit.

gold_sents: On June 21, 2016, individuals who had been forced to pay a $50 "extension fee" for inability to pay their monetary penalties in full, or go to gail for non-payment of court fines and costs, brought a putative class action lawsuit in the District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Bogalusa City Court and the sole judge who sits on the Bogalusa City Court, under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging that the defendants (1) systematically jail and threaten to jail individuals who cannot pay fines and court costs that fund the city court; and (2) have created an illegal extension fee to generate additional revenue.[SENTMARKER]Shortly after U.S. District Court Judge Ivan L.R.[SENTMARKER]Lemelle denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and held their request for a preliminary injunction in abeyance, the parties decided to explore settlement options.[SENTMARKER]They filed a stipulated agreement with the District Court, which was granted.

gold_sents: On June 20, 1989, foster care children of the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights and the ACLU, asked the court to order improved policies related to protective services, family preservation and preventive services, child placement, case reviews, adoptions, and staffing, among other issues, claiming violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (AACWA), the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District of Columbia Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, and the District of Columbia Youth Residential Facilities Licensor Act of 1986.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that caseloads were too large, leaving many children in the foster care system for far too long with unresolved cases.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the complaint alleged inappropriate placements for children and inadequate efforts to return children home.[SENTMARKER]In 1993, Judge Thomas F. Hogan approved a consent decree directing DHS to develop policies and procedures to rectify the system.[SENTMARKER]After many years of oversight, and periodic contempt orders, the system has gradually improved.[SENTMARKER]However, there is still a monitor in place reporting on the progress of the Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA) created as a result of this case.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In November 1993, the Center for the Study of Social Policy and Children's Rights, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services and the Governor of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District was violating the Constitution, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act of 1977 and the Youth Residential Facilities Licensure Act of 1986 by failing to develop policies and procedures for the reporting investigation of child abuse and neglect, failing to return children to their homes on a periodic basis, and failing to report child abuse or neglect.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the District to submit a plan to remedy the violations of the Constitution and the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, as well as a plan for monitoring the District's foster care system.[SENTMARKER]The District agreed to implement the plan, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: California recipients of Adult Day Health Care services brought this class action to enjoin California from reducing or eliminating the ADHC program, which would put the plaintiffs at risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California granted the plaintiff class a preliminary injunction in September 2009, forbidding California to modify it's adult Day Health Care program until an appropriate alternative could be provided to prevent institutionalization of individuals in the plaintiffs' class.[SENTMARKER]The District Court approved a settlement agreement that created a new program which will help to prevent the institutionalization of ADHC beneficiaries.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.

gold_sents: On August 11, 2005 a group of African-Americans filed a consolidated amended complaint Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in United States District Court of the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Wal-Mart discriminated against African-Americans in hiring of over-the-road truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]On May 16, 2007, the court certified a class of African Americans who had not been hired or had been deterred from applying for these jobs.[SENTMARKER]Discovery continued in preparation for trial and on January 13, 2009 the court denied the defendant's motions for decertification and summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties thereafter reached a settlement that was approved by the court on March 5, 2009.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement Wal-Mart agreed to damages in the amount of $17,500,000 to be distributed to the named representatives, class members, and their attorneys.[SENTMARKER]It also agreed to provide EEO training, actively recruit minorities, impose benchmarks for hiring minority drivers, make specific job opportunities open to minorities, and engage in recordkeeping and reporting.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.

gold_sents: On August 16, 2019, several health care providers and nonprofit organizations serving immigrant communities filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Department of Homeland Security's Final Public Charge Rule (the Rule), which added non-cash benefits to the factors considered in determining whether a person applying for legal permanent residence is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Government violated the Administrative Procedure Act by exceeding its statutory authority, claimed that the Rule was "arbitrary and capricious," and asserted that the Rule violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, a district court judge denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction enjoining the government from implementing the Rule, but issued an order for preliminary injunction in a related case that would enjoin the implementation of the rule in California, Oregon, the District of Columbia, Maine, and Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]This preliminary injunction was stayed by the Ninth Circuit in December 2019.[SENTMARKER]It was affirmed a year later in December 2020, but the order was stayed pending petitions to the Supreme Court in the Second, Seventh, and Ninth Circuits.[SENTMARKER]The Rule was abandoned by DHS on March 9, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of April 15, 2021, the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This is a class action lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a South Carolina immigration law which requires state and local law enforcement officers to investigate the immigration status of any individual they stop, detain, or arrest whenever they have a "reasonable suspicion" that the individual lacks immigration status, allows law enforcement officers to arrest individuals solely for failing to carry registration documents, makes it a crime to harbor or transport an undocumented immigrant or to be harbored or transported by others if one is an undocumented immigrant, and imposes civil liability on the police for failing to enforce its provisions to the maximum extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The law was patterned after Arizona's SB 1070.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the law, and this injunction has been appealed to the Fourth Circuit; in the meantime, the case, along with several others like it from different states, are stayed at the District Court or U.S.[SENTMARKER]Appellate level pending the decision of the Supreme Court in United States v. Arizona.[SENTMARKER]After Arizona v. United States was decided the issue was remanded to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court left in place most of its original preliminary injunction, enjoining the state from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6 (B)(2).[SENTMARKER]The 4th Circuit per Judge Davis agreed and affirmed the order on July 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]In March of 2014 Judge Gergel permanently enjoined South Carolina from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6(B)(2).[SENTMARKER]Furthermore the state agreed to more favorable interpretations of Section 7, and the remainder of Section, encouraging the Plaintiffs to dismiss their claims on those sections without prejudice.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.

gold_sents: In July 2008, the plaintiffs sued the City of Tenaha under the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection).[SENTMARKER]They claimed that law enforcement officials in and around the City of Tenaha have developed an illegal practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from people who appeared to be non-white or who were traveling with non-white passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they had been victims of such stops and seizures of amounts up to $50,000, as well as false prosecution or detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]Their proposed consent decree included: video and audio recordings of all stops; written documentation with details of the stop; no more dog searches in routine traffic stops; written and oral consent for a search; all asset forfeiture revenue must be donated to nonprofits or used for audio/video equipment or training; and use of an impartial monitor.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree, which it later extended to early 2021 after the plaintiffs alleged noncompliance by the City.

gold_sents: On September 28, 2020, the Massachusetts Fair Housing Center and Housing Works, Inc. filed a complaint against the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Secretary of HUD in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the defendants under the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 702-703, alleging that a new HUD rule (“the 2020 Rule”) limiting disparate impact claims under the Fair Housing Act was contrary to law and arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to enjoin the defendants from implementing the 2020 Rule until after this case was resolved and filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on October 6, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ motion on October 25, 2020, finding that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claim that the 2020 Rule was arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On June 4, 2013, plaintiffs, natives of Mexico who had agreed to voluntary departure from the United States, filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Central District of California under the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA"), 8 U.S.C. §1101, and state law against the acting director of Homeland Security, U.S. Customs and Border Protection ("CBP") and Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement ("ICE").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant's agencies in southern California violated INA by coercing plaintiffs into accepting voluntary departure through misstatements, omissions, threats, and/or pressure in violation of defendants' own regulations.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on March 11, 2015, where defendants agreed to allow applications from the class members that would enable their return to the United States and their legal position prior to acceptance of voluntary departure.

gold_sents: On July 10, 2018, the ACLU of Northern California filed this FOIA suit against U.S. Immigrations and Customs Enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought records pursuant to a FOIA request about the defendant's use of a contractor to process and transport immigration detainees, some of whom had allegedly suffered injury and death due to the contractor's malfeasance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought an order from the court that the defendant provide the records.[SENTMARKER]This case was combined with a suit from a private plaintiff alleging mistreatment in ICE and G4S custody in July 2019.[SENTMARKER]Document production appears to be continuing smoothly at a rate of 750 pages per month, but shifting production online due to COVID-19 has yielded some issues in getting documents over to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]Document production is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California (ACLU-NC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and G4S, a private contractor providing transportation services for immigration detainees in the San Francisco area.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU alleged that ICE’s efforts to detain individuals, to 17 transport them to detention centers throughout the country, and to increase the use of private transport services for ICE detainees violated the Freedom of Information Act (F.I.A.)[SENTMARKER]and the Constitution’s Fourteenth Amendment right to a fair and open government.[SENTMARKER]On January 25, 2018, the ACLU-NC filed a FOIA request to ICE seeking documents relating to the detention and transportation of immigration detainees.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request was denied, and on April 12, 2018, the court granted the ACLU's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2019, the court ordered ICE to produce documents at a rate of 750 pages per month, up from 500 pages.[SENTMARKER]In the last case management conference on September 26, 2019 the Court ordered a 19 increase in the size of ICE's production from 500 page per month to 750 pages.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, the State of California filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and ICE.[SENTMARKER]The State alleged that the rescission of the in-person learning exemption for F-1 and M-1 visa students in the July 6 Directive violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Department's March 13 Guidance.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the State's motion for a preliminary injunction, and the Court issued a permanent injunction on July 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The injunction prevents Defendants from enforcing an action that violates the APA.

gold_sents: In 2020, two immigration detainees in the Batavia Federal Detention Facility in Batavia, NY, filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they and others similarly situated had been improperly denied bond, that non-bond alternatives to detention had not been properly considered by their immigration judges, that such considerations were required by the Immigration and Nationality Act, and that the policy of placing the burden of proof on the Plaintiffs to show they posed no flight risk violated their Fifth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief for pre-hearing detainees, agreeing that they pled sufficient facts to state a Due Process Claim that the government is required to bear the burden of proof at bond hearings for individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1226(a).[SENTMARKER]It denied Plaintiffs' request to certify the putative post-hearing class.[SENTMARKER]Both parties appealed; the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This suit seeks to support Texas's law Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the suits that seek to challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order, this suit aims to support the work of federal immigration officials.[SENTMARKER]There are, so far, four cases addressing SB4.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2017, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed this suit seeking a declaratory judgment approving SB4.[SENTMARKER]Defendants are Travis County, City of Austin, and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF).[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction on May 24, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice to refiling on August 9, 2017, finding that Texas lacked actual or imminent injury, which was required for Article III standing to seek declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Texas appealed to the Fifth Circuit, who affirmed the district court's dismissal of the claim on December 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: Two detainees in Shelby County Jail in Tennessee filed this petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that failure to take sufficient COVID-19 precautions violated the Fourteenth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and they sought release.[SENTMARKER]The court appointed an "Independent Inspector" to assess conditions at the jail and, based on his report, denied preliminary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied defendants' motion to dismiss, and a trial is scheduled for May 2021.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Inspector was tasked with inspecting the jail to evaluate the conditions.[SENTMARKER]While praising defendants' professionalism, he wrote that several adjustments needed to be made in order for the jail to be a safe place for detainees.[SENTMARKER]After attending mediation and filing a joint motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement, the court preliminarily granted the consent decree requiring monthly reports on the status of COVID-19 in the Jail and unannounced, periodic inspections by the Inspector.[SENTMARKER]A final approval hearing is scheduled for March 5, 2021.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 14, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California ruled that the National Security Letter (NSL) statute was facially unconstitutional under the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court enjoined the government from issuing 5 NSLs or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court held that the NSL law, as amended, was constitutional.[SENTMARKER]The NSL statute remains unconstitutional.
