gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 30, 2004, a class action lawsuit was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of qualified welfare beneficiaries who claim to have been deprived of federally sponsored cash assistance, food stamps and Medicaid benefits in violation of federal and state law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to make eligibility determinations regarding food stamp and Medicaid applications at Job Centers separate from the eligibilitydeterminations regarding cash assistance applications.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion to certify as a class and granted their motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of this Court's holding that the State did not have a duty to oversee and supervise the City defendants to ensure compliance with federal and State law.[SENTMARKER]On February 14, 2005, the Court of Appeals, Cardamone, vacated the district court's injunction and remanded the case to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a permanent injunction requiring the City to provide emergency food stamps to eligible beneficiaries within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applicants when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](ii) send notices to applicants confirming their eligibility; .[SENTMARKER](iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing Forms W145HH and M3; and (v) document such withdrawals pursuant to New York Social Services Law  133.

gold_sents: Three indigent persons charged with crimes filed a class action lawsuit in Skagit County Superior Court against the City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington alleging defendants failed to provide adequate assistance of counsel.[SENTMARKER]The Cities jointly contracted with two attorneys to handle all public defense assistance cases, and each attorney handled over 1,000 cases per year.[SENTMARKER]The Court found the plaintiffs established their rights were systematically deprived and the Cities were responsible for the deprivation.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief requiring the City of Mount Vernon and City of Burlington re-evaluate their contract for the provision of public defense services and hire one part-time public defense supervisor.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The City of Mount Vernon, Washington and the City of Burlington, Washington were sued in the Skagit County Superior Court for failing to provide adequate funding for their public defense system.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in order to challenge the constitutional adequacy of the system provided by the City.[SENTMARKER]The Court found that plaintiffs’ Sixth Amendment rights were violated.[SENTMARKER]The Cities were kept apprised of these numbers and the Court MEMORANDUM OF DECISION 1 required the Cities to provide funding for indigent defense.

gold_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2018, CNN and two of its employees filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the White House, President Donald Trump, and several of his officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking the press credentials of CNN's chief White House correspondent, Jim Acosta.[SENTMARKER]The defendants initially claimed that they revoked Acosta's press credentials because he "plac[ed] his hands" on an intern.[SENTMARKER]But that is insufficient to justify such a substantial restriction on Plaintiffs' First Amendment rights.

gold_sents: When mass protests against police violence were exempted from New York’s COVID-19 gathering restrictions, but congregational worship continued to be prohibited, two Catholic priests and three Orthodox Jews brought this lawsuit, alleging that New York officials were discriminating against people of faith.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 26, 2020.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 26, 2020, the city of Albany, New York and the Catholic Diocese of Albany filed a lawsuit against the city’s Department of Health and the Archdiocese of New York in federal court in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of the New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had exempted mass protests against racism from gathering restrictions.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the parties agreed to a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The injunction will remain in effect until a permanent injunction is granted.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The court found that official acts of state agencies contributed to the racial segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The majority opinion approves the District Court's conclusion that a Detroit only integration plan would be insufficient to cure the unconstitutional segregation found to have been imposed in the Detroit city schools.
